title: Application of the Cross-Correlation Technique to Evaluate Profile Data

author: Rohan Perera, Soil and Materials Engineers, Inc.

segmentation: Now for the third presentation.
Very important issue for road and also highway agencies is the accuracy of the collected data they get from the contractors.
Cross correlation technique for validating the output of initial profiles will be presented by Doctor Orkin Pereira.
Doctor Oken Pereira is a senior project engineer with soil and materials engineers in Michigan, USA.
He obtained his PhD specializing in payments from Arizona State University.
He has over 15 years of experience in profile data analyzes.
Good afternoon the time.
Love my presentation is application of cross correlation technique to evaluate profile data.
First of all I would like to acknowledge my coauthors stock own.
Mark Swanland from Federal Highway Administration, who is with us in.
Audience and Robert Ortmeier
In the United States, state highway agencies have smoothness specifications for new payment construction as well As for rehabilitated payments.
The contractor must meet the smoothness level that is specified in the smoothness specification.
So perhaps in Europe you call it the the amount of uneven unevenness that is specified in the specification.
If the contractor fails to move, meet that specified smoothness level, the contractor has to pay a penalty.
If the contractor achieves a smoothness level that is better than the specified level, many state highway agencies will give a bonus to the contract.
Contractors use their own profiling equipment to collect smoothness data on new construction.
The State Highway Agency will do some random checks on a sample of projects.
But the State Highway Agency does certify contractor own profilers annually to make sure that they are collecting accurate profile data.
These are some photographs of.
The three types of profilers that are used in United States.
To collect data.
We use high speed profilers.
Then we use.

Lightweight profilers and this kind of a profiler can get on a concrete payment as soon at it as it as hard, and you know like within 24 hours you can profile a concrete payment using a lightweight profile.
Then we also have portable profilers which can be connected to a truck hitch at the behind any truck.
The traditional method for certifying profilers has been to lay out one or two test sections that are typically 150 meters slow.
And then you collect data on this test section using a reference device.
A reference device is something that you deem to be capable of collecting accurate data.
Thereafter, the profiler makes several repeat runs on the test section.
And then you calculate the YRI from the data collected by the profile.
Then you can use either the standard deviation of the YRI or the coefficient of variation of IRRI.
To see if the profile the YRI values obtained by the profiler meets a specified threshold.
If it's meet that specified threshold, we say the profiler is capable of collecting repeatable data.
Then we get the average IR A that you get from the profiler from the repeat runs and compare it with the YRI from the reference device.
If this difference in YRI between the profiler and the reference device is within a certain threshold level.
We say the profiler is collecting accurate data, so if a profiler.
Passes the repeatability criteria and this accuracy criteria.
The profiler is certified.
No, some questions have been raised about.
If this traditional method of certifying profilers is good enough now when you go and collect profile data, let's say over a length of 150 meters, you can calculate an IRRI value.
That IRI value gives you an average IRI for that 150 meter long section.
It does not tell you anything about how the YRI is distributed within that section.
We can look at the distribution of YRI within the section by looking at a continuous roughness plot or a continuous YRI plot.
An this graph shows continuous roughness YRI plots for two runs collected by a profiler at a site.
Anne, this continuous roughness plot is based on a 7.6 metre basically.
What that means the IR I shown at any distance is the average IR eye over a 7.6 metre length centered on that location.
So if you look at the YRI that is shown at a distance of 100 meters.
That is, the IRI from 96 the average YRI over the over the length 96.2 meters 203.8 meters, which is 3.8 meters before 100 meters and 3.8 meters after 100 meters.
So if you look at these two continuous YRI plot, you see there are some significant differences in the distribution of YRI within this section.
But if you look at the average IR right, that's the overall YRI for this 150 meter long section.
You see for the run one you get 1.25 meters per kilometer.
For Run 2 you get 1.24 meters per kilometer.
So if you look at the overall YRI, you could say these two runs are giving me identical YRI values.
But if you look at a continuous roughness plot that shows how the YRI is distributed within the section, you can see there are some substantial differences between these two runs of the profile.
So therefore Asheville, which is American Association of State, Highway and transportation officials.
Came out with a new standard called PP 49.
For certifying inertial profilers, and that users, a technique called cross correlation and it's based on cross correlation of YRI filtered profiles.
Now usually when we calculate I are.
You know we have a computer program, we select a profile and you just hit a button and that will give you IRRI values.
Now let's look and see.
What happens inside this IRI computation program?
So you have a profile and within the IR A computation program.
The program does a simulation of 1/4 car on the profile.
Aquatica is basically 1/4 of a car, so you have.
Right over here the body weight.
The which is 1/4 of the weight of the car.
Then you have the suspension system, the tire and the tire is represented by your spring.
And the simulation of the quarter car on the profile is performed at a speed of 80 kilometers per hour an the the weights.
The spring constants and these properties of the dashpot, all of the fixed inside that computer program.
So once you do the computer simulation.
You come up with this IR A filtered profile.
In this original profile, your elevations are in middle readers in this YRI filtered profile, your Y axis is slow, so it's meters per kilometer.
And when you calculate the YRI of the entire segment, you take the absolute values.
Of these slopes, and you average them.
That's how you get the YRI for the entire section.
So in this cross correlation technique we do cross correlation between 2 profiles.
So you have profile one.
An use put it through the IR A algorithm and you get IRRI filtered profile one.
Then you take the second profile.
Put it through the IR A algorithm and you get IR.
I filtered profile 2.
Then we compare.
These YRI filtered profile one and I are.
I filtered profile 2 using a technique called cross correlation.
Basically that.
Techniques compares to these two filtered profiles to see how well they agree with each other.
If they agree perfectly, you get a cross correlation value of 100.
If there's no agreement whatsoever, you get a value of 0.

Now I'm not going to go into the mathematics behind this cross correlation technique, but if anyone is interested I can give a reference later on where they can refer to the mathematics behind cross correlation.
How do you do cross Corelation?
There's a software called Profile and it's available free.
You can download it from this website.
Ann, you must have your data in a format called ERD format.
Which is basically a text file with some headers.
An if you go to search on the Internet for ERD file.
You can find details about that.
The good thing about this software, although it was developed in United States, it can handle data in metric units.
So anyone in the world can use this software, which is available for free.
To not only do cross correlation, but all kind of analysis involving profile data.
We perform an experiment to see how well this cross correlation technique applies to data that we collect in the real world.
And we did this experiment at a place called Min Rd which is located in Minnesota.
And this is a test Rd.
It's not subjected to traffic except for control traffic that they use to apply loading.
So this is a very good place to do all kinds of experiments.
An we used.
Several reference profiling devices.
An universal profiler.
In this Expo.
Island.
Be used.
ARB is Australian Rd research board walking profile.
This is a device that you push along the payment and you can get elevation data at 240 millimeter intervals.
Then we use 2 devices that that that are called Sir Pros.
This is a rolling.
Uh.
Rolling profiler with you push along the payment at walking speeds around 3 kilometers per hour.
And it can record elevation data at 25 millimeter intervals.
We had two of these devices.
Then we had another serpro.
From the same manufacturer, the only thing is it had a wider tire compared to the other.
2 devices.
Then we had another walking profiler which I'm going to refer to as the device B.
Then we had.
A lightweight inertial profiler.
And this was equipped with two sensors that were in line with each other.
This particular sensor is called a roller in sensor and it's manufactured by Celko.
It is a line which is 100 millimeters long and there are 100 data points within that 100 millimeters.
And you can use a breeching algorithm on that data so that you eliminate effects of texture.
This sensor was developed.
To address issues that we have been facing with singlepoint lasers on diamond ground payments and on longitude iterate longitudinally tide concrete payments.
And this sensor is called a tryout sensor.
It has three dots and this was also developed to address issues with longitudinal tide concrete payments.
So both of these sensors were mounted in the lightweight profile.
We use two dissections, an asphalt dissection, Anna concrete dissection, and each of these test sections was 150 meters long.
With the reference devices we did three runs and with the profiler we did five runs.
So if you look at the different runs for a device you will notice that the YRI values are very close to each other.
And then if you look at the average IR A values for all these devices, the YRI values are very close to each other.
There they range from 1.39 to 1.43.
And here are the IR A values on the concrete section.
You will see the same trend.
Very repeatable data by your profiler.
Anne.
The average values are very close to each other.
They range from 1.19 to 1.23.
No, we applied the cross correlation technique on this data.
To see what kind of results we will get.
Now for these reference profilers, we have three runs.
You can apply the cross correlation.
For only two runs at a time, So what we do is.
We take run number one and run number 2 and calculate the cross correlation, then one versus 3 and then two versus 3 and average them.
So the values that we have shown on this slide are the average cross correlation values by comparing all possible all possible combinations for a given profile.
The ash to PP 49 addresses.
Only profilers it does not address reference profilers and according to AASHTO PP 49 standard.
It says for a profiler to be repeatable you must get.
Cross correlation.
I have said here as equal to 92 it should be greater than or equal to 92.
So your cross correlation is if it's greater than equal to 92.
For a profiler, you say the profile is repeatable and this is and the value given in the ash to standard is based on 10 repeat runs for a profiler.

For this experiment, we didn't have the time to do all these runs, so the values that I have shown here for the reference profiler are based on three runs, while for the Universal Profiler it's based on five runs.

An recall for the Universal profiler there were two sensors an I have shown the repeatability values for both sensors, but there's another publication that looked at reference profiler cross correlations that says reference device.
Much be capable.
Of achieving a cross correlation of 98% and you can clearly see in this asphalt section the ARB Profiler Walking Profiler and this device B.
Did not do that.
Well.
Then let's look at the concrete section.
The RRB did better.
But still this device be had a low cross correlation.
Now let's look at the IR A filtered profile for Device B.
Now, if you remember and the the earlier table, you will see the YRI values for this profile for repeat runs were very close to each other.
But if you look at the YRI filtered profile, you'll see there are some significant.
Difference is now why do we care?
About profile repeatability.
When we are certifying profilers.
Becausw in the United States we use.
A continuous IRI plot.
To detect rough locations.
Remember I showed you a continuous roughness plot at the start of my presentation, which was based on the base length of 7.6 meters.
From such a plot, you can look at the distribution of YRI within a payment segment.
And locations that have high our eyes.
Are put locations where you can have bumps on the pavement?
So that's why I are a distribution.
Is extremely important, that's why all these reference divisors as well as inertial profilers that we use in construction acceptance must be able to capture the YRI distribution very accurately.
Because we look at rough spots.
Using a continuous YRI plot.
And then the contractor can go to those locations, detect the bump and grind it.
So as you can see.
For this particular device, it wasn't doing very good in its IRRI filtered profiles, although its overall YRI for the entire segment was very close to each other for the two runs.
Here is the IR.
I filtered profile for a serpro.
I mean this had a cross correlation of about 98%.
That this shows that the two YRI filtered profiles overlay with each other extremely well.
So this is what we need for the equipment to be repeatable.
Anne.
And then we looked at.
Reproducibility that is comparing devices among each.
Each other.
So right here, this is the reproducibility between the Sir provide tier and the ARRB.
Now again, recall that you can do cross correlation only for two profiles, so in this case.
We take run number one from ARB and do the cross correlation with run number one from this.
Sorry, yes, run run number one from the Servpro cross correlated with run number one from ARB, then one V2 one with three.
Then go to run #2 from Servpro.
Do it with one from ARB 2, three and four three repeat runs for each device.
You will have 9 combinations, so you do the cross correlation for all nine combinations and these are the average values.
And as you can see.
All reproducibility cross correlations involving this device B.
Is extremely low.
Wait for the others.
Yo, you get some high values now you do expect high reproducibility between the Sir Pros because they are all from the same manufacturer.
But you can see the RV and also the other Servpro said good high cross correlation.
And if you look at the inertial profiler both sensors had high cross correlations with all reference devices except for this device V.
Similar results.
For concrete payments.
So.
Now for conclusions.
We see from this experiment that the cross correlation method is superior to the traditional method of certifying profiles.
Now if we if we were using the traditional method of certifying profilers, we would not have detected the problem with profiler be.
We would have said.
All these devices look great.
But when we use this cross correlation technique, we were able to detect there is a problem with one particular profile.
And this experiment validated the procedures in ash to PP.
49 because based on our experiment we could see that this procedure can be used successfully to certify profiles.
One thing to keep in mind.
About cross correlation or any profile experiment is to make sure.
All your devices collect data along the same path.

It's very easy to do that with the reference profiler, but you know, like when you're using a high speed profiler and collecting data at 80 kilometers per hour, it becomes a little bit more challenging.
But you try your best to collect data along the same path, otherwise you know you are not going to be.
You could be comparing data collected along a different path.
With the reference data that was color.
Collected along another path, so the difference in cross correlation may be related to equipment as well as driver error.
So this is one thing you have to keep in mind when you're collecting profile data.
For any comparison, make sure you collect data along the same path.

The other thing to keep in mind when you applying this cross correlation technique is you have to make sure the start location for both data that I'll be datasets that are being correlated start exactly at the same point, but.
If there is a small discrepancy, proval will take care of it.
Profile keeps one profile fixed and it moves the other profile.
Around a specified distance that the user can input in order to locate.
The position that gives you the hyest cross correlation, so that is taken care of.
Within the program.

But still, in order to make sure that you collect data for the entire test section, it's important that you start data collection exactly at the start of the section an in data collection at the end of the section.
So this concludes my presentation and I gave you an overview.
Off the way, we do construction acceptance in the United States and how we certify profilers in the United States.
Thank you.
